abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the Customs Development
            Project for Russian Federation were as follows: outcomes
            were satisfactory; risk to development outcome was moderate;
            Bank performance was satisfactory and borrower performance
            was also satisfactory. Some lessons learned includes:
            customs (in fact all revenue administration) reforms can
            succeed only with strong high level political will and
            commitment complemented by sustained technical support from
            the entity itself. A medium to long-term strategic vision,
            owned by the implementing agency, is a prerequisite for
            sustained revenue administration reform and
            capacity-building. Successful customs reforms must address
            institutional constraints to customs performance, and not
            center reforms exclusively on information technology and
            systems solutions. Business process re-engineering and
            related automated applications must be fully (though
            gradually) integrated throughout the customs administration,
            with appropriate management of the organizational transition
            (including human resource and training aspects) as central
            elements of this process. Creation of a sustainable revenue
            administration system requires changes to the policy/legal
            and institutional frameworks as well as administrative
            actions to support institutional reforms. Strong and
            consistent support for customs modernization from the head
            of customs is essential for sustained reform. A dedicated
            project implementation/management team needs to work
            effectively with key operational parts of customs in
            supporting and coordinating reforms, rather than succumbing
            to time-driven pressures and becoming directly involved in
            implementing reforms. Appropriate sequencing of
            reform/modernization activities is critical to their success
            and to the achievement of intended development outcomes.
            Complex, risky and longer-term public sector institutional
            reforms can often benefit from World Bank support in
            significant ways, not often appreciated or understood.
